settings.seo_content:
At PEARL iZUMi, we believe in connecting people to the world around them through the power of cycling. Our cycling gear is designed to enhance every ride, ensuring you have the best experience possible. Whether you're a seasoned rider or just starting, our collection offers performance-driven comfort and style.

Cycling Gear for Every Discipline

Our range includes apparel and accessories for road cycling, mountain biking, commuting, and more. Each piece is crafted to meet the specific needs of different cycling disciplines, ensuring maximum performance and protection. From moisture-wicking jerseys to durable gloves, our gear is built to last and keep you comfortable in all conditions.

Choosing the Right Cycling Gear

Selecting the right cycling gear is crucial for a safe and enjoyable ride. Consider factors like fit, material, and weather conditions. Our products feature innovative technologies like BioViz® for visibility, PI Dry® for water resistance, and PRO Transfer fabric for optimal moisture management. Explore our collection and find the perfect gear to match your riding style and needs.

From lightweight, breathable jerseys to advanced water-shedding technology, our new arrivals redefine cycling comfort and performance. Explore designs tailored to inspire confidence and keep you riding in all conditions.

Performance-Driven Comfort

Push your limits with gear engineered to excel in every ride scenario. Our apparel features premium materials, ergonomic designs, and cutting-edge innovations for ultimate performance.

All-Weather, All-Terrain

No matter the weather or terrain, our gear is designed to keep you going. Waterproof jackets, thermal gloves, and moisture-wicking fabrics make every ride a possibility.

Sustainability at the Core

As part of our commitment to protecting the planet, our new arrivals incorporate eco-friendly materials and processes. Ride confidently knowing your gear is as kind to the earth as it is to you.

Gear for Every Cyclist

From seasoned pros to weekend warriors, our collection offers something for everyone. Find versatile pieces that blend function with style, tailored to your unique ride.

Join the Ride

Take your cycling experience to the next level with PEARL iZUMi’s latest arrivals. Answer the call of the road, trails, or city streets and experience the freedom only two wheels can provide. The time is now—explore our new collection today.

PEARL iZUMi's road cycling gear is designed to elevate your ride. Whether you're a weekend warrior or an all-in performance cyclist, our apparel and accessories are crafted to meet your needs. From lightweight jerseys to durable shorts, we provide comfort and performance for every road adventure.

Performance Apparel for Every Condition

Our road cycling gear is built to handle all weather conditions. With advanced moisture-wicking fabrics and all-weather protection, you can focus on the journey, not the elements. Explore our collection to find the perfect gear for sunny days, rainy rides, and everything in between.

How to Choose the Right Cycling Gear

Choosing the right cycling gear is essential for comfort and performance. Consider the fit, material, and features of each piece. Our apparel is designed with the cyclist in mind, ensuring you have the best experience on every ride. From chamois selection to jersey fit, PEARL iZUMi has you covered.

Cycling shorts are an essential piece of gear for any cyclist, providing comfort and support during long rides. Men's cycling shorts come in a variety of styles, including bib shorts and traditional shorts, with different features to suit different disciplines and personal preferences.

Cycling Shorts & Bib Shorts

The primary difference between men's cycling shorts and bib shorts is the way they are designed. Traditional cycling shorts have an elastic waistband, while bib shorts have straps that go over the shoulders. Bib shorts are preferred by some cyclists because they eliminate the need for a waistband, which can cause discomfort or restrict movement during long rides.

Cycling Shorts per Discipline

Road Cycling Shorts: Road cycling shorts are designed to be aerodynamic and lightweight, with a close fit that reduces drag. They often have a chamois pad that is thinner than other types of cycling shorts, which is ideal for road cyclists who spend a lot of time in the saddle.

Gravel Cycling Shorts: Gravel cycling shorts are designed to provide comfort and support during long rides over rough terrain. They often have a more relaxed fit than road cycling shorts, with a thicker chamois pad to absorb shock.

Mountain Biking Shorts: Mountain biking shorts are designed to be durable and protective, with features like reinforced seams and padded inserts. They often have a baggy fit to accommodate knee pads and other protective gear.

Indoor Cycling Shorts: Indoor cycling shorts are designed to be breathable and moisture-wicking, with a comfortable fit that allows for a full range of motion. They often have a thicker chamois pad to provide extra cushioning during intense indoor cycling sessions.

How to Choose the Best Shorts

When choosing the best cycling shorts for your needs, consider factors like the type of cycling you'll be doing, the fit of the shorts, and the level of comfort you require. Look for shorts with a chamois pad that is appropriate for your discipline, and choose a size that fits snugly but comfortably. For more tips on choosing the best cycling shorts, check out our guide.

Men's cycling shoes are an essential piece of gear for any cyclist, providing optimal power transfer, stability, and comfort during rides. Whether you're a road cyclist, mountain biker, or prefer indoor cycling, investing in a quality pair of cycling shoes can greatly enhance your performance and overall experience on the bike.

Cycling Shoes for Different Disciplines

Road Cycling Shoes: Designed for road cyclists, these shoes prioritize lightweight construction, stiff soles, and efficient power transfer. They often feature a three-bolt cleat system compatible with most road pedal systems. Road cycling shoes offer a snug fit and optimal ventilation to keep your feet cool during long rides.

Gravel Cycling Shoes: Gravel cycling shoes are versatile options suitable for mixed-terrain adventures. They combine features of road and mountain bike shoes, offering a balance between comfort and performance. These shoes typically have a two-bolt cleat system for compatibility with mountain bike pedals, allowing for easier walking off the bike.

Mountain Bike Shoes: Men's mountain bike shoes are designed for off-road trails and rugged terrains. They feature durable construction, grippy outsoles for traction when walking or hiking, and a two-bolt cleat system for compatibility with mountain bike pedal systems. Mountain bike shoes often provide additional protection and reinforcement to withstand the demands of off-road riding.

Indoor Cycling Shoes: For indoor cycling enthusiasts, there are specialized shoes designed specifically for stationary bikes. These shoes typically have a two-bolt cleat system and prioritize breathability and comfort. They often feature adjustable closures for a secure fit and are compatible with most indoor cycling pedals.

How to Choose the Best Men's Cycling Shoes

Discipline: Consider the type of cycling you'll be primarily engaged in. Road cyclists should opt for lightweight, stiff-soled shoes, while mountain bikers may prioritize durability and traction.

Size and Fit: Proper fit is crucial for comfort and performance. Ensure the shoes provide adequate toe room, a secure heel grip, and a snug but not overly tight fit. Sizing can vary between brands, so consult the manufacturer's size chart or try them on before purchasing.

Closure Systems: Cycling shoes come with various closure systems such as Velcro straps, ratcheting buckles, or BOA dials. Choose a closure system that allows for easy adjustment and a secure fit.

Cleat Compatibility: Check the cleat system compatibility of the shoes and ensure they match your preferred pedal system.

Comfort and Ventilation: Look for features like breathable uppers, mesh panels, and ventilation ports to keep your feet cool and dry during rides.

Remember, it's essential to try on multiple brands and models to find the right cycling shoes for your needs. Consider visiting a local bike shop for expert advice and fitting assistance.

For more detailed guidance on choosing the best men's cycling shoes, check out our comprehensive guide.

Women's cycling shoes are essential gear for female cyclists, providing comfort, support, and performance during rides. Whether you're a road cyclist, gravel adventurer, mountain biker, or indoor cycling enthusiast, finding the right pair of shoes can significantly enhance your riding experience.

Cycling Shoes for Different Disciplines

Road Cycling Shoes for Women: Road cycling shoes are designed for efficient power transfer and long-distance riding on smooth pavement. They feature stiff soles for maximum energy transfer and often have a three-bolt cleat system compatible with road bike pedals. Look for lightweight construction, breathable materials, and a secure closure system for a snug fit.

Gravel Cycling Shoes for Women: Gravel riding demands versatile footwear that can handle various terrains. Gravel cycling shoes typically combine features of road and mountain bike shoes. Look for shoes with a balance between stiffness and walkability, grippy outsoles, and compatibility with two-bolt cleat systems.

Mountain Bike Shoes for Women: Mountain biking requires durable shoes with excellent traction, protection, and flexibility. These shoes often have grippy rubber outsoles, rugged construction, and a two-bolt cleat system for compatibility with mountain bike pedals. Consider shoes with added toe and heel protection, ample ventilation, and a secure closure system.

Indoor Cycling Shoes for Women: Indoor cycling shoes are specifically designed for use with stationary bikes or indoor cycling classes. They typically feature breathable uppers, stiff soles for efficient pedaling, and a two-bolt cleat system compatible with most indoor cycling pedals. Look for shoes that offer proper ventilation and an adjustable fit for long, sweaty workouts.

How to Choose the Best Women's Cycling Shoes

Discipline-Specific Considerations: Determine the type of cycling you'll primarily be doing to select shoes tailored to that discipline. Consider factors such as sole stiffness, cleat compatibility, grip, and protection.

Size and Fit: Proper fit is crucial for cycling shoes. Measure your feet accurately and refer to the manufacturer's sizing guide. Pay attention to width options if you have narrower or wider feet. Try shoes on and ensure a snug, but not overly tight, fit to prevent discomfort and hot spots.

Comfort: Look for features that enhance comfort, such as cushioned insoles, breathable materials, and ample ventilation. Consider any specific foot issues you may have and choose shoes that accommodate them, such as models with adjustable closures or roomier toe boxes.

Closure Systems: Consider the closure system that suits your preferences. Popular options include traditional laces, hook-and-loop straps (Velcro), and dial closures (Boa). Each offers different levels of adjustability and convenience.

For a more comprehensive guide on choosing the best women's cycling shoes, check out our detailed guide. Find the perfect pair that matches your riding style and enjoy improved performance and comfort on every pedal stroke.

Cycling socks are an essential accessory for any cyclist, providing both comfort and functionality during rides. Designed specifically for the demands of cycling, these socks offer features that enhance performance and keep your feet cool, dry, and comfortable.

Types of Cycling Socks

Cycling socks differ from regular socks in several ways. Firstly, they are made from specialized materials that wick away moisture and promote breathability, keeping your feet dry and reducing the risk of blisters. Secondly, they often have reinforced areas, such as the heel and toe, to enhance durability and cushioning. Lastly, cycling socks are typically taller than regular socks, extending above the ankle to provide additional support and protection.

Cycling Socks per Discipline

When it comes to cycling socks, different disciplines have varying requirements.

For road cycling, where speed and aerodynamics are crucial, sleek and lightweight socks are preferred. They offer a snug fit and minimal padding to minimize bulk and maximize efficiency.

Gravel cycling requires socks that can handle rougher terrains. Look for socks with extra cushioning in the heel and toe areas to absorb impact and reduce discomfort during long rides on uneven surfaces.

Mountain biking demands durable and protective socks. Opt for socks with reinforced construction and thicker materials to withstand the rigors of off-road riding. They should also provide ample ankle coverage to protect against debris.

Indoor cycling, such as spinning or indoor training, benefits from socks that prioritize breathability and moisture-wicking properties. Look for socks with mesh panels to ensure proper ventilation during intense indoor workouts.

How to Choose the Best Cycling Socks

To select the best cycling socks, consider the following factors:

  1. Material: Look for socks made from moisture-wicking and breathable fabrics like merino wool or synthetic blends.
  2. Fit: Ensure the socks fit snugly without being too tight or restrictive. They should stay in place during rides.
  3. Cushioning: Determine the level of cushioning you prefer based on your riding style and the terrain you typically encounter.
  4. Height: Choose the sock height based on your personal preference and the level of support you need.

settings.title: Any Weather Trail Wear
settings.text: Our three-season line-up of cold weather trailwear dials breathability, so you’ll spend less time shedding layers and more time shredding singletrack. Get ready to charge the climbs, rip the descents, and keep rolling whatever the weather.The right gear is all you need to extend the season.

settings.body:
Our three-season line-up of cold weather trailwear dials breathability, so you’ll
spend less time shedding layers and more time shredding singletrack. Get ready
to charge the climbs, rip the descents, and keep rolling whatever the weather.
The right gear is all you need to extend the season.

settings.title: cool
settings.text: When the weather shifts, and it’s time to add a little insulation, reach for a pair of lightweight pants and a breathable thermal top. When combined with midweight gloves and lightweight Merino wool socks, you have a kit that strikes the perfect balance between retaining warmth downhill and releasing heat on the climbs. A durable water repellent (DWR) coating on the pants helps to shed tire spray, protecting your legs and backside from the chill.

settings.title: Cold & Windy
settings.text: When the trees lose their leaves and the wind whips through the forest, it’s nice to have a little extra protection from the elements. Gear like the Summit AmFIB® Lite pants adds wind and water protection where it’s needed most while still prioritizing breathability. Up top, a thermal layer pairs perfectly with the new Summit ECOLoft™ Vest or super-packable Summit PRO Barrier Jacket. And don’t forget something for your ears and extremities, like the warm-yet-precise Summit Alpha Glove and cozy Merino Thermal socks.

settings.title: Cold and Wind Ready MTB Gear
wet
settings.text: If winter in your neck of the woods means rain instead of snow, shifting into the dark months is more about staying dry to keep comfortable. Our WxB gear is designed to help you maintain a stable microclimate, providing rain protection while prioritizing breathability. A jacket with an over helmet hood, like the Summit PRO Neoshell®, prevents water from running down your back on the trail and adds surprising comfort. The new Summit WrX Neoshell glove keeps your digits drier so you can hit your brake points with confidence.

settings.title: deep winter
settings.text: Riding deep in the winter months can leave you feeling you’re somehow cheating the system and getting bonus trail days. The truth is, with a smart layering strategy and the right gear, it can be some of the most rewarding riding of the year. When winter hits, riders have been turning to AmFIB softshell for decades. Items like the Summit AmFIB Alpha pant and Canyon ECOLoft Jacket provide the perfect balance of insulation and ventilation, so trail efforts don’t leave you clammy an hour into the ride. Add shoecovers, under helmet ear protection, and our legendary winter gloves, and you’re ready for the trails on even the coldest days.

settings.title: Limited Edition PEARL iZUMi Collections
settings.text: Our inspiration always starts with the ride. Limited edition kits, created by our in-house design team, include small batch jerseys, bibs and more, all inspired by the way we ride and revel in Mother Nature’s wonder.

settings.title: The Landmark Project x PEARL iZUMi
settings.text: Shop our limited edition collaboration with The Landmark Project, celebrating Old Fall River Road in Rocky Mountain National Park - while supplies last!

settings.title: Grateful Dead x PEARL iZUMi: Ten Spot Edition
settings.text: Showcasing artwork from the album Dave’s Picks Vol. 20, the Ten Spot Collection is an ode to the band’s 1981 ten-day tour in Colorado.

settings.title: Grateful Dead x PEARL iZUMi: Wanderer Edition
settings.text: Just like riding at sunrise or sunset, anyone who’s been to Colorado’s famous Red Rocks Ampitheater knows the light show is something to behold. We created this collection in celebration of the band’s July 1978 performance at the iconic outdoor venue.

settings.title: Grateful Dead x PEARL iZUMi: Rambler Edition
settings.text: For the Rambler in all of us. We paid homage to the band’s distinctive florals, in this limited edition collection designed to pay tribute to the natural world that inspired so much of the band’s catalog. Launched 50 years after the group launched their European ‘72 tour with their barn-burning performance at London’s Wembley Empire Pool.

settings.heading: IT’S GOOD TO BE IN THE BIKE BUSINESS.
settings.body: Bikes are good for people and can be good for the planet. But we don’t think it’s good enough to just be in the right business, we want to do business the right way. And because the materials we use and the emissions we create to manufacture our products directly affect the places we all ride, we’re committed to actively confronting climate change.

settings.subtitle: OUR PLEDGE TO YOU & THE PLANET:
settings.title: Title goes here
settings.text: Because we believe how we live shapes how future generations ride, we pledge to use our business practices, products and advocacy to reduce our oil consumption and embolden all of us to ride more, do more.

settings.text_1: Getting started with riding isn’t easy, but if you stick with it day-in and day-out it becomes second nature. It’s about committing to a goal, staying focused on the long game, and constantly learning. That’s our philosophy when it comes to finding the most sustainable business model.
settings.text_2: To inform our big picture supply chain decisions, we rely on the rigorous research conducted by the Higg Index, an international sustainability model.
settings.text_3: We partner with the Renewal Workshop to repair returned items that can then be reused.

settings.subtitle: PRODUCT:
settings.title: BUILT FOR YOU, BUILT TO LAST
settings.text: If you’re looking to make sustainable purchasing decisions, we have your back. Every day we move towards manufacturing more of our products using recycled, renewable, and/or organic materials. In fact, we’re on track for 98% of the items we make to be sourced from sustainable materials by 2024. And we build our gear to last, backed by our Lifetime Guarantee and free inhouse repairs.

settings.text_1: The notion that bikes make us better and are better for our planet is at the core of our advocacy work. We partner with action-focused organizations committed to expanding cycling infrastructure and increasing access to bikes. We’re proud to work with these groups to create more vibrant and sustainable communities.
settings.text_2: We’re supporting All Kids Bike critical mission to teach every child in America how to ride a bike in kindergarten PE class.
settings.text_3: We continue to partner with People For Bikes as they work to get more people riding bikes more often. And to make bike riding better for everyone.
settings.text_4: We see IMBA as an important ally as they aim to create, enhance and protect great places to ride mountain bikes.

settings.title: HOP ON OUR WHEEL
settings.text:
We’re proud to lead the charge for environmental change in the cycling industry.

To join the chase for a more sustainable future, we encourage you to make mindful purchasing decisions and to ride as much as you can as part of your lifestyle.

Remember progress is a process and we’re in it together.

settings.title: Title
settings.text: Text

settings.title: Why this matters
settings.text:
Quite simply, the more good we do,
the more we (and you) can enjoy the world by bike.
Our social purpose is based on the idea
that we can be a force for good —
as a business, as bicyclists and as neighbors.

It’s not enough to just make gear for riding,
we’ve committed as a company to
make a positive impact.

settings.heading: THEREFORE, OUR PLEDGE
settings.body:
Because we believe how we live shapes how future generations ride, we pledge to use our business practices, products and advocacy to reduce the consumption of oil and embolden all of us to ride more, do more.

How we do it.
Our pledge is brought to life within three areas:
BUSINESS, PRODUCT & ADVOCACY.

settings.subtitle: Commitment #1
settings.title: BUSINESS: Progress not perfection
settings.text: We are continually, obsessively, evaluating our business to turn a critical eye on our environmental impact and identify optimizations to improve our operations. We focus on long term behaviors vs. short term fixes. It’s the only way to create truly meaningful change.

settings.title_1: Printed Catalogs are in the past
settings.text_1: We printed our last catalog in the fall of 2017. Sales representatives & dealers now have access to a fully-features digital platform. Through the elimiation of this paper we are saving annually: 82 trees, 2,222 gallos of oil and 13,60000 gallos of water.
settings.text_2: We use a standardized framework called the HIGG Index which is an international measurement tool for the apparel and footwear industry to assess environmental and social sustainability throughout the supply chain. At PEARL iZUMi, we'll take those measurements, compare industry benchmarks and build future-facing strategies to improve our impacts and become a more sustainable busines.

settings.subtitle: Commitment #2
settings.title: PRODUCT: Better, longer, with less waste
settings.text: Our products are the epicenter of our impact. That’s why we are a proud industry leader in sustainability and environmentally-responsible manufacturing. We create products to last longer and avoid replacement while employing some of the most innovative, environmentally-conscious materials in the industry.

settings.title_1: Small Actions Have A Big Impact
settings.text_1: Effective January 2019, we are the first bike brand to essentially "eliminate" hangtags. Critical information will be found on the one tag the size of a business card, the smallest size that can be recycled. Through the reduction of this paper we are saving annually: 165 trees, 4,503 gallos of oil and 68,882 gallons of water.
settings.title_2: A Second Life Better than the first
settings.text_2: Our products now ship in polybags made from 100% recycled plastic, which can be recycled again. We also reduced our overall material use by evaluating and changing how our products are folded and packaged to use smaller polybags.

settings.subtitle: Commitment #3
settings.title: ADVOCACY: We are our community
settings.text: We believe bikes make us better, and therefore do all we can to get more people on bikes in the hope of creating more vibrant communities. Our advocacy is action focused, compelling us to support organizations that have proven their power in creating more riders and more places to ride.  To find out more, please visit our dedicated advocacy page.

settings.title: WE RIDE OUR TALK
settings.text: We embrace with enthusiasm our opportunity to create positive impact. From our day-to-day business to our leading voice within the cycling industry, we are committed to leaving our world a better place to ride.

settings.heading: How to Build Your First Road Cycling Outfit
settings.body: The bike is just the start of your journey. If you’re new to riding — or if it’s been 10 years since you’ve swung a leg over a top tube — you have a lot of new clothing and accessory innovations to take your riding to the next level. We know sorting through it all can feel overwhelming. But little extra investment will reap dividends in the saddle and set you on the right path.

settings.heading: So, let’s get you outfitted for a fantastic future on the road.

settings.title: Bibs and Shorts
settings.text: It's a personal preference. Shorts stop at the waist. Bibs have straps that ride over the shoulder that hold the chamois in place and eliminate the waistband, reducing compression on the gut. Yes, bib shorts can be a hassle to wrestle out of for a pitstop. Yet we still almost always reach for these on a road ride. Their easy compression around the waist allows for easier breathing, and the straps hold the chamois close to the body, providing an overall more comfortable fit.  The padded chamois is made from layers of breathable foam that cushion the bum, buffing out road vibrations. The chamois is held in place with Lycra panels that compress muscles for support and reduce chafing. Together, they allow the rider to pedal effortlessly through the miles. Bike shorts are meant to be comfortably compressive; you don't want loose fabric as it will lead to chafing.  Cycling bibs and shorts are meant to be worn without underwear. Awkward, maybe; comfortable, yes.

settings.title: Cycling Jersey
settings.text: A proper jersey fits svelte, quickly wicks away moisture, is cut longer in the back for coverage, and has a row of pockets slung low over the back to provide easy access to supplies. The jersey is also an opportunity to personalize your look. You’ll have reams of color options to sift through to mix and match with your socks and helmet, allowing you to dial in a look.   Not all jerseys fit the same. Choose a Form-Fit cut if you want a slightly compressive, close to body fit that doesn’t flap in the wind. For a classic look that fits close to body, but not tight, opt for Standard Fit. And if you’d rather error on the side of roomy, go for Relaxed Fit.

settings.title: GLOVES
settings.text: Riders have three contact points with the bike: the foot, the butt, and the hands. A good pair of gloves have a touch of padding, damping road vibration. Choose fingerless gloves for hot summer days. For cooler rides, use a pair of fingered gloves that block wind and offer insulation. Take it from us, cycling with cold, wet hands is like enduring the ice bucket challenge — only for hours, not seconds. Gloves keep the digits nimble enough to use the levers.  More padding doesn’t always mean more comfort. Too much padding can prevent proper positioning and cause fatigue. That’s why we carefully 3D shaped our pads to put the right amount of padding just where your hands rest on the bars, giving you the most comfort and control.

settings.title: SOCKS
settings.text: Socks aren’t just another way to dial in your look; the bright colors help you be seen by drivers on the road. They come in many lengths, but, thanks to Lance Armstrong, the current trend has a bias for midcalf length.   Socks should be comfortable, stay put, and meet the conditions you’re riding in. Thin and airy are good for hot summer days; wear a bit thicker Merino wool sock for cooler days.

settings.title: SHOES
settings.text: Linking the rider to the bike, a proper road shoe is stiff, transferring force from the legs to the road. A well-fitting shoe will be snug–but not tight–with some room for the toes to wiggle. The heel should feel locked in the shoe’s counter and shouldn’t slip up or down.  Traditional road shoes have a sleek, firm outsole made of nylon or carbon fiber with pedal cleats mounted over the sole, making them efficient on the bike. But they can be uncomfortable to walk in. This leaves many new riders asking, “Do I need a dedicated road shoe?” Purists will groan, but we say no. Some riders use one pair of shoes for both mountain and road cycling. If “there can be only one” in your wardrobe, but you have two bikes in the stable, we recommend a gravel-friendly shoe. These are durable and walkable without sacrificing that road flare. The fashion police will give you a pass.  Tip: Traditional road shoe cleats are mounted to the sole through three bolts (while a mountain bike shoe uses a two-bolt mechanism). The shoe you choose will inform your pedal decision and vice versa.

settings.title: wind vest or jacket
settings.text: The cycling jacket’s goal is to keep you warm and dry, with “dry” being relative. Unless you regularly ride in the rain, a jacket doesn’t need to be waterproof. A waterproof jacket will trap sweat on the inside, making you wet anyway. Instead, we almost always carry a water-resistant wind jacket treated with a durable water-repellent finish.  The fit should be snug and the material should be light. This simultaneously reduces wind flap and allows the jacket to stow away in a pocket. If you ride in town, our reflective BioViz® accents to catch the eye of passing drivers in low light conditions.   Our best-selling Quest Barrier Convertible Jacket is a good start. This relaxed-fit wind jacket sheds light rain and helps block the wind in unpredictable weather. As things heat up, the sleeves zip off and disappear in a jersey pocket and unpack with a big punch when the road tilts down and chill factor becomes real.

settings.title: arm and leg warmers
settings.text: Rides often start early and end some 20 degrees later. Arm warmers and leg warmers slip over limbs, allowing you to adjust your thermostat as the temperatures change. They are easy to pull off and tuck away into the jersey with little fuss.   Like bibs and jerseys, arm and leg warmers come in a variety of sizes. Find the right fit for your guns, as you don’t want the warmers to slip off. To help prevent them from falling down, layer arm and leg warmers under the jersey and bibs.

settings.title: baselayers
settings.text: A baselayer will help keep you in the comfort sweet spot as temperatures fluctuate, but especially in cooler weather. They fit close to the body, under your bib straps, and pull sweat quickly off your skin.  In warmer temps when you’re sweating more a baselayer will improve your cooling, to a point. We don’t recommend them above 90.  In cooler weather, the baselayer keeps you dryer and warmer. Choose a polyester Transfer base for all condition use, or cozy Merino wool for cooler rides.

settings.heading: FRESH AIR IN THE LUNGS,
settings.body: dust on the legs, sweeping landscapes in view — hitting the trail reaps huge physical and mental rewards. But if you’re putting rubber to the dirt for the first time, it can be a little intimidating. The right gear can make the transition to mountain biking more enjoyable.

settings.heading: We’ve outlined the basics to get you out and on the trail for miles of joy.

settings.title: Jerseys
settings.text: Hot days on the trail are paid out in liters of sweat. You need a jersey that breathes well and wicks sweat quickly. Mountain bike jerseys fit looser for better airflow and are offered in sleeveless, T-shirt, zip front and tank styles. But don’t assume their casual styling means they’re any less technical.

settings.title: Shorts
settings.text: For mountain bikers, shorts provide as much protection from the unpredictability of the trail as they do the saddle. Padded Lycra bike shorts can pass in a pinch, but over time they will take a beating on the trail. Investing in a pair of dedicated mountain bike shorts will prove a better option.

settings.title: shoes
settings.text: More durable than gym shoes, a dedicated mountain bike shoe provides a stable platform to transfer energy from your legs, through the bike, to the ground. Mountain bike shoes fall into two categories: flat pedal and clipless. Both should feel stiff, yet comfortable, and lock your heel into the cup. The choice depends on the type of riding you’ll do (and your comfort with unclipping from the bike).  Stepping off a flat pedal has zero learning curve, making it safer to tackle rocky terrain. Clipless pedals (contrary to the name) “clip” onto your shoes through a cleat bolted between the lugs. The cleats snap into the pedal, locking your foot into the bike. Twisting your foot unlocks it from the pedal. It takes some practice, but clipping into the pedals allows you to pull up and push down with each pedal stroke, providing maximum energy transfer between you and the trail. These are a great choice for more cross-country-oriented rides that don’t require constantly stepping in and out of the pedal.

settings.title: gloves
settings.text: Gloves are one part grip, one part protection. Sweat or rain can make your grip slick. Gloves will keep you connected to the handlebars, prevent blisters, and, if you go down, you will appreciate the coverage. Even for sunny summer rides, we like full-finger gloves. A good pair should be lightweight and nimble, allowing you to work the levers without overheating.

settings.title: liners
settings.text: You still need a chamois to protect your backside. The good news is that many MTB shorts include a padded liner short, but you can also choose to buy the outer short and liner separately if you want higher performance comfort.

settings.title: socks
settings.text: Socks wick moisture away from the feet, offer a bit of cushioning, and can protect the lower legs from flogging by brush. Cycling socks are some of the very best socks you can buy. They stay up, are durable, and they’re fashionable enough to cross over into everyday wear. Taller socks can provide a little more protection, support, and warmth.

settings.title: jackets
settings.text: Backcountry weather can be fickle. Summer afternoons can quickly shift from sunny to stormy in the flick of a gear. Like hikers, mountain bikers should prepare for the worst. Every rider should stow a simple jacket in the pack to unfurl with the change of weather.   A waterproof-breathable jacket can protect you from a rainstorm, but it can often be too warm (and bulky) for riding. Unless you regularly ride in the rain, most riders will be better served with a water-resistant jacket. This will have a DWR coating to shed light rain, while the lightweight material helps cut through the wind and disappears in the pack. On cold morning rides, these jackets provide fantastic warmth when you point the rubber down the hill.

settings.title: protection
settings.text: Terrain changes quickly when mountain biking, especially on trails you’re unfamiliar with. As you start to point the rubber down more technical terrain, consider knee and elbow pads. Protecting your knee and elbow joints ensures you’ll be ready to ride another day. A good pad will have some pre-curve to fit around the joint while allowing it to articulate.

settings.title: MISSION & VALUES
settings.text: We don’t see ourselves as just a cycling company. We’re part of a much bigger mission. We unlock the power of inspiration & impact. It’s why we show up to work and it’s what keeps us moving forward, together. We’re committed to connecting more people to cycling and empowering them to go by bike, because we think bikes help us live a deeper, richer and more rewarding life.

settings.title: Therefore, it’s our mission to:
settings.text: Inspire a spirit of freedom and performance for cyclists everywhere, and a love of cycling for future generations. Positively impact people, communities and the environment. And we do this by living five core values, which guide our decisions and shape our perspectives on the world around us. You’ll find these values literally etched  in the floors and walls of our headquarters, but more importantly, in the hearts of every PEARL iZUMi employee.

settings.heading: Our values are more than words. We live them, encourage them and protect them day in and day out.

settings.title: Trust
settings.text: Whether protecting you from the elements or being transparent about our business, we see trust as a core product attribute and a building block of a responsible business.

settings.title: Craft
settings.text: We were founded by a passionate craftsman. His attention to detail, quest to innovate the material and the making of it, and passion for precision guides our hand in the creation of every product and program we develop.

settings.title: Empathy
settings.text: We believe that understanding what riders think and feel is the first step in developing gear to truly serve their needs. Our experience shows that connecting and listening is a major driver for meaningful innovation.

settings.title: Impact
settings.text: We strive to make the biggest positive impact on our cycling community and the absolute smallest negative impact on our environment. After all, our ability to ride our bikes is afforded by a healthy planet on which to ride.

settings.title: Plus 1
settings.text: Our passion for riding and the belief that bicycles are part of the solution for many of the world’s current challenges motivates us to push a little more. The better we do our jobs the more we share the stoke.

settings.title: How to Choose Cycling Shorts
settings.text: Choosing the right cycling shorts is key for comfort and performance, whether you're riding road, gravel, or mountain trails. Start with the fit—shorts should be snug but not restrictive, allowing free movement without bunching. A quality chamois is crucial for long rides, providing essential cushioning. Road cyclists benefit from lightweight, moisture-wicking fabrics, while gravel riders need durable, abrasion-resistant materials. Look for features like leg grippers to keep shorts in place and stretchy fabrics for mobility. The right shorts can greatly enhance your comfort, no matter the ride.

settings.heading: The Right Shorts Take You Where You Want to Go
settings.body: Choosing the right bike shorts comes down to two factors—function and feel. What type of riding do you plan to do and what shorts make you feel your best? We offer performance-built shorts that run the gamut—from smooth and fast tarmac, techy singletrack, to the wide array of gravel riding that falls somewhere in between. Where you take your bike may dictate some key features in your kit, as well as how long you plan to ride.

settings.title: Road
settings.text: When choosing road cycling shorts, it's important to consider both comfort and performance, with the right fit varying by skill level. Beginners should focus on shorts with a well-padded chamois (the cushioned insert) that reduces friction and absorbs road vibrations without adding bulk, while pro cyclists may prioritize lightweight fabrics with multi-density padding for enhanced performance and aerodynamics. The fit should be snug, moving with your body to prevent chafing, and remember that men’s and women’s cycling shorts are designed to be worn without underwear to maximize the moisture-wicking and friction-reducing benefits of the chamois. Our advanced Levitate chamois, featured in the shorts collection, provides next-level comfort with its innovative, independent suspension layers, ensuring you stay comfortable whether you're tackling long rides or intense sprints.

settings.title: Cycling Bibs or Shorts
settings.text: When choosing between cycling shorts and cycling bibs, the decision often comes down to your riding style and personal comfort. Cycling shorts, including men's and women's bike shorts, are typically preferred by beginners or those who prioritize ease of wear, as they're simple to slip on and off. In contrast, cycling bibs are favored by more experienced riders and those tackling longer rides, especially on the road or gravel. Bibs offer superior chamois stability without the pressure of a waistband, which can increase comfort over extended distances. Whether you're a pro or just starting out, the key is to find padded shorts that provide optimal support, like our Levitate chamois. With options designed for men and women, our feature-rich bibs and shorts are crafted to perform in any condition, ensuring you’re ready for the road ahead.

settings.title: Features to Look For
settings.text: When shopping for cycling shorts, consider which features make the most sense for your style of riding. BioViz reflective elements for safety, and silicone grippers on the legs of our shorts and bibs are standard, but it’s also worth considering whether you’re going for a lunchtime ride or an all-day excursion, or whether you’re logging miles on the indoor bike or hauling camping gear on a gravel bike. Our new adventure-minded Expedition shorts and bibs offer low profile cargo pockets to stash essentials. We also offer varying inseam lengths for a customized fit – from our PRO Bib Short – short inseam for men, to our Women’s Sugar 5” Short. Shop our Men’s and Women’s PRO shorts for the ultimate in comfortable compression with minimal seams and our Levitate PRO Chamois.

settings.title: Shop by Collection
settings.text:
We’ve built our name on making the best shorts in the cycling industry - innovative
designs, sustainable materials, unmatched riding comfort, and performance.

settings.cta_info_1: Our iconic Quest Collection features a value-packed relaxed fit
settings.cta_text_1: For roomier fits and approachable styling, our Quest line is designed for everyday riding.
settings.cta_info_2: Shop Attack for comfortable compression and sleek details
settings.cta_text_2:
If value and performance matter most, reach for our Attack collection. Designed with
comfortable compression and modern tech, our Attack collection packs a punch.
settings.cta_info_3: Our PRO Line offers luxurious high-performance fabrics and a next-to-skin fit
settings.cta_text_3:
The PRO series represents everything we’ve learned throughout our decades in the
cycling industry: cutting edge tech, elevated performance, and our most compressive fit.

settings.title: Trouble deciding?
settings.text:
Looking for size advice? Need to know how our shorts compare to another brand? Our
customer care team - made up of real-life cycling fanatics - is available to help!

settings.title: fit meets function
settings.text: The tried-and-true rules of cycling apparel—spandex on tarmac, baggies on trail—became trends for good reason. On the road, snug, muscle-hugging bibs move with you, not against you, ensuring next-to-skin comfort as you pedal. The svelte design creates less wind resistance and improves fabric performance, so you’ll stay drier, cooler, and more comfortable. And because traditional road jerseys have back pockets there is no need for pockets on the shorts—but trends are starting to change (read on for more about our Cargo shorts).

settings.title: Mountain Bike
settings.text:
Mountain bike shorts split focus between durability and stretch, while adding other adventure features like secure pockets for snack storage. Unlike road shorts, mountain bike shorts have two independent pieces, a “shell” outershort and “liner” undershort. The liner has the compression of a standard bike short to help hold the integrated padded chamois in place, which adds comfort on the trail. Because these pieces are independent, you can purchase them together or separately, so pay attention to the description.

Of course, some riders choose compression road shorts for mountain biking and baggy shorts for the road, so do what you’re most comfortable with.

settings.title: We think about chamois, so you don’t have to
settings.text: There’s no reason for discomfort to limit time in the saddle. Bike shorts offer the most comfortable ride by doing two things really well— reducing skin friction and providing cushion on a bike seat. The chamois is the key. These padded inserts have a soft wicking face to keep your skin dry, and over a centimeter of highly breathable foam to support your body at your contact points.  Not all chamois are created equal, which is why we’ve been designing ours in house for more than 40 years. It helps us ensure the best materials and allows us to push the pace of innovation. Investing more in your bike shorts means a better chamois. Premium chamois offer plusher comfort longer into your ride without adding bulk.  You can choose from three levels in the PEARL iZUMi line: PRO, ELITE, or SELECT.

settings.heading: find your perfect short

settings.text_1: Traditional cycling shorts are designed to provide comfortable compression, with inseams long enough to cover the thigh for muscle support. Bib cycling shorts trade a compression waistband for stretchy support straps giving you the most comfortable riding experience, and are favored over standard shorts by most experienced riders
settings.text_2: If you’re not a fan of the bike-short look but want the pedaling performance, these sporty styles are your best bet. All include a comfortable chamois.

settings.title: Cargo Cycling Shorts
settings.text: Cargo shorts have all the advantages of traditional bike shorts but with pockets to carry a phone and snacks, or handle trash. If you don’t want to wear a pocketed cycling jersey, or simply want more carrying capacity, cargo shorts are a must-have.

settings.text_1: Perfect whether you need something to wear under a mountain bike shell short or a pair of gym shorts for an at home workout. These liner shorts are made with highly breathable sweat-wicking materials andinclude a friction-fighting chamois.
settings.text_2: These lightweight pedal-friendly shorts are perfect if you’re planning to hit some singletrack. And all include chamois liners, so you’ll be ready to ride.

settings.title: of course,
settings.text: these categories are just our guidelines—the best shorts are the ones you want to ride in!

settings.title: TECHNOLOGY
settings.text:
In 1964 PEARL iZUMi was started by one
man with a penchant for experimenting
and a vision for what cycling apparel
could become. Since then, we’ve hung
onto that vision and have experimented
tirelessly to innovate and refine our
products. Our team of engineers and
designers are committed to offering you
the best technical gear to outfit your
adventures. We have deep roots but we’re
always looking forward.

settings.text_1: BioViz® is a proprietary hi-visibility system designed to increase rider visibility for drivers by leveraging human biology. We employ a unique combination of fluorescent colors and strategically placed reflective elements that demand the viewer’s attention. Our standards ensure riders are not only seen but seen with enough time for drivers to react safely, day or night.
settings.text_2: In 1983, we made the first synthetic chamois and forever changed cycling apparel. Since then, we’ve been on a mission to continue innovating where it matters most. Our top-end chamois technology sets a new bar for performance-minded riders, and we apply the same thinking and quality standards to all price points because everyone should ride in comfort.

settings.text_1: Barrier fabrics provide lightweight, breathable wind protection. Combined with a durable water repellent (DWR) technology, they offer enough water shedding performance to protect you from brief rain showers, with better packability and breathability than a truly waterproof fabric.
settings.text_2: Transfer fabrics are made with technical fibers designed to transport perspiration away from the body, promoting faster evaporation and helping you stay cool and dry. Perfect for warm to hot days and against the skin as part of a layering system for cooler conditions.

settings.text_1: WxB fabrics are designed for consistent rain. They use waterproof/breathable membranes combined with taped seams to create a watertight seal yet still allow water vapor and warm air to escape, so you are less likely to overheat or feel chilled from sweat. These fabrics are combined with a durable water repellent (DWR) technology to shed precipitation.
settings.text_2: Ideal for winter or cool-wet conditions, AmFIB softshell fabrics combine breathable protection from wind and water with lofted fibers to retain body heat. While these fabrics provide substantial moisture protection, they emphasize breathable insulation and are not fully waterproof. Garments made with AmFIB provide consistent comfort through a range of cool-to-cold conditions so you can minimize layering adjustments.

settings.text_1: Our Thermal fabrics provide consistent warmth during aerobic riding activity. They use lofted moisture-moving technical fibers to retain warm air while encouraging perspiration to evaporate, so you stay dry and feel warmer. Garments made with Thermal fabrics can be worn as an outer layer for cool conditions or as a mid-layer on the coldest days.
settings.text_2: GoFresh provides odor control by helping to prevent bacteria growth in fabrics during and after exercise. We use only natural anti-bacterial tech or natural fiber blends, so the fabrics are safe for your skin and the planet. After your ride, just hang the GoFresh garment to dry, and it will be ready for at least one more lap before you wash. Ride more, wash less.

settings.text_1: In-R-Cool technology helps keep you in the comfort zone when the mercury rises so that you can perform better in hot conditions. In-R-Cool boosts the natural cooling properties of our technical Transfer fabrics beyond simple sweat evaporation without changing the look or texture.

PI Dry® technology provides water shedding performance at the fiber level, allowing us to create knit and woven fabrics that repel water regardless of how much they stretch. Water rolls off, keeping you warmer, drier, and lighter. And the best part is, it lasts longer than DWR’s, delivering full performance even after 100 washes.
settings.text_2: D3O offers the most minimal yet most advanced MTB protection against impact. Guards using D3O remain flexible until impact, then firm up to disperse the energy of the blow. The body contoured design makes D3O guards comfortable to wear all day. Made for riders who want to push their limits.

settings.text_1: Polartec® Alpha® active insulation is engineered to deliver consistent warmth while allowing greater breathability during aerobic activities like cycling. Designed to regulate comfort in changing conditions, these fabrics also feel great next to the skin.
settings.text_2: Polartec® NeoShell® provides the performance of waterproof fabric while still allowing dynamic air exchange. Unlike traditional waterproof/breathable membranes, Neoshell is breathable before you begin to overheat, making it ideal for cycling.

settings.text_1: Polartec® Delta® is a next-to-skin fabric that better utilizes the body’s natural cooling process—sweat. It works more efficiently by elevating touch-points for increased airflow, faster moisture dispersal, and reduced wet-cling. Ideal for hot weather riding.
settings.text_2: PrimaLoft Gold with cross-core technology is constructed with ultra-light aerogel particles, the lightest material on earth. This insulation allows us to create garments with unmatched thermal performance without the bulk.

settings.body:
Here we go. It’s our mantra. It reflects our belief that people on bikes can be agents of change,
and it should be a powerful reminder of the strength of inclusion.

We are committed to building, fostering and encouraging a stronger cycling community through inclusivity. With a focus on our headquarters, retail locations, our ambassadors, and our broader communities, we have established Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion goals related to four main categories:

COMMIT. We are dedicated to representing cycling’s diversity internally and externally.

EDUCATE. We are increasing our team’s cultural competency through educational experiences.

DIVERSIFY. We are committed to attracting and retaining a diverse PEARL iZUMi team.

INCLUDE. We are creating space to actively include all forms of riders and allies of the cycling community, from all backgrounds in our community.

The benefits of riding are well known, for health, community, the environment, and individual happiness, and we’re here to share them far and wide.

settings.heading: The causes we're helping affect.
settings.body: We support these likeminded, non-profit organizations because we not only believe in what they do, we believe in creating a better world for endurance athletes for generations to come.

settings.title: Craig Hospital-Pedal 4 Possible
settings.text:
Craig Hospital in Denver, Colorado, is a world-renowned rehabilitation hospital that exclusively specializes in the neuro-rehabilitation and research of patients with spinal cord injury (SCI) and brain injury (BI).

Pedal 4 Possible is a charity ride benefiting Craig Hospital patients and programs. All money raised will fund innovative therapy programs that help Craig Hospital patients experiencing spinal cord and brain injury.

settings.title: PeopleForBikes
settings.text:
PeopleForBikes Coalition is a membership organization founded by bicycle industry leaders with the mission of putting more people on bikes more often.
PeopleForBikes lobbies for bicycle friendly policy on Capital Hill, promotes bicycling to the public and distributes grants for bicycle facility projects by working with political leaders and national advocacy groups. We’ve supported this program since 2002.

settings.title: IMBA
settings.text:
IMBA creates, enhances and preserves trail opportunities for mountain bikers worldwide.
Since 1988, IMBA has brought out the best in mountain biking by encouraging low-impact riding, volunteer trail-work participation, cooperation among different trail user groups and innovative trail management solutions.

settings.title: Trips for Kids
settings.text:
Trips for Kids is a non-profit that provides mountain bike outings and environmental education for inner city, low income and at-risk-youth across the U.S. and Canada.
TFK opens the world of cycling to at-risk-youth through day-long mountain bike rides and afterschool Earn-A-Bike programs. The goal of their youth bike programs is to combine lessons in personal responsibility, achievement and environmental awareness through the development of practical skills and the simple act of having fun.

settings.body:
We understand that you can't combat capricious weather with a cookie-cutter approach to outerwear. Our collection includes everything from packable water repellent emergency shells for "just in case" protection to purpose-built waterproof rain jackets for riders who won't take a day off during downpours.

Now's the perfect time to update your wardrobe to keep you warm and dry this spring and shrug off cold weather, so you'll never have to miss a ride. Shop by weather condition below.

settings.title: Rove Barrier Jacket
settings.text: This casual jacket includes all the technology you’ve come to expect from us, plus some special details to improve your ride.

settings.title: Torrent WxB Jacket
settings.text: This lightweight jacket sheds water like no other thanks to our PI DRY® finish, which offers permanent water repellency for a lifetime of performance. We used a stretch nylon fabric to achieve a close-to-body fit that still allows for movement on the bike. A highly breathable water-proof membrane and taped seams provide absolute protection, with rapid moisture vapor transfer to keep you dry inside. A high collar helps keep the rain out and the cut is just generous enough to accommodate layers beneath. And it’s packable enough to easily stash in a jersey pocket.

settings.title: PRO Insulated Jacket
settings.text: Imagine a cycling jacket that is soft, warm and manages moisture no matter what the conditions. Thanks to ultra-soft PolarTec Alpha Direct insulation and a highly breathable membrane, this jacket delivers, without the bulk. It’s warm enough that a base layer is all you need underneath to stay comfortable on all but the coldest days. It features two zippered front pockets as well as a rear zippered pocket for storage.

settings.title: Women's Road Beginners Guide
settings.text: Use overlay text to give your customers insight into your brand. Select imagery and text that relates to your style and story.

settings.heading: How to Build Your First Road Cycling Outfit
settings.body: The bike is just the start of your journey. If you’re new to riding — or if it’s been 10 years since you’ve swung a leg over a top tube — you have a lot of new clothing and accessory innovations to take your riding to the next level. We know sorting through it all can feel overwhelming. But little extra investment will reap dividends in the saddle and set you on the right path.

settings.heading: So, let’s get you outfitted for a fantastic future on the road.

settings.title: Bike Shorts
settings.text: Shorts or bibs it’s a personal preference. Shorts stop at the waist. Bibs have straps that ride over the shoulder that hold the chamois in place and eliminate the waistband, reducing compression on the gut. Yes, traditionally bib shorts have been a hassle for women to wrestle out of for a pitstop, but our women’s bibs have an easy to use drop tail design that makes them as convenient as shorts.  The padded chamois is made from layers of breathable foam that cushion the bum, buffing out road vibrations. The chamois is held in place with Lycra panels that compress muscles for support and reduce chafing. Bike shorts are meant to be comfortably compressive; you don’t want loose fabric as it will lead to chafing.  Cycling bibs and shorts are meant to be worn without underwear. Awkward, maybe; comfortable, yes.

settings.title: Jerseys
settings.text: A proper jersey fits svelte, quickly wicks away moisture, is cut longer in the back for coverage, and has a row of pockets slung low over the back to provide easy access to supplies. The jersey is also an opportunity to personalize your look. You’ll have reams of color options to sift through to mix and match with your socks and helmet, allowing you to dial in a look. And if you’re not into the look of a traditional jersey, you can find tanks from us with the same functionality. Not all jerseys fit the same. Choose a Form-Fit cut if you want a slightly compressive, close to body fit that doesn’t flap in the wind. For a classic look that fits close to body, but not tight, opt for Standard Fit. And if you’d rather error on the side of roomy, go for Relaxed Fit.

settings.title: Gloves
settings.text: Riders have three contact points with the bike: the foot, the butt, and the hands. A good pair of gloves have a touch of padding, damping road vibration. Choose fingerless gloves for hot summer days.  For cooler rides, use a pair of fingered gloves that block wind and offer insulation. Take it from us, cycling with cold, wet hands is like enduring the ice bucket challenge only for hours, not seconds. Gloves keep the digits nimble enough to use the levers.

settings.title: Socks
settings.text: Socks aren’t just another way to dial in your look; the bright colors help you be seen by drivers on the road. They come in many lengths, but, thanks to Lance Armstrong, the current trend has a bias for mid calf length.   Socks should be comfortable, stay put, and meet the conditions you’re riding in. Thin and airy are good for hot summer days; wear a bit thicker Merino wool sock for cooler days.

settings.title: Shoes
settings.text: Linking the rider to the bike, a proper road shoe is stiff, transferring force from the legs to the road. A well-fitting shoe will be snug–but not tight–with some room for the toes to wiggle. The heel should feel locked in the shoe’s counter and shouldn’t slip up or down.  Traditional road shoes have a sleek, firm outsole made of nylon or carbon fiber with pedal cleats mounted over the sole, making them efficient on the bike. But they can be uncomfortable to walk in. This leaves many new riders asking, “Do I need a dedicated road shoe?” Purists will groan, but we say no. Some riders use one pair of shoes for both mountain and road cycling. If “there can be only one” in your wardrobe, but you have two bikes in the stable, we recommend a gravel-friendly shoe. These are durable and walkable without sacrificing that road flare. The fashion police will give you a pass.  Tip: Traditional road shoe cleats are mounted to the sole through three bolts (while a mountain bike shoe uses a two-bolt mechanism). The shoe you choose will inform your pedal decision and vice versa.

settings.title: Wind Vest or Jacket
settings.text: The cycling jacket’s goal is to keep you warm and dry, with “dry” being relative. Unless you regularly ride in the rain, a jacket doesn’t need to be waterproof. A waterproof jacket will trap sweat on the inside, making you wet anyway.  Instead, we almost always carry a water-resistant wind jacket treated with a durable water-repellent finish. The fit should be snug and the material should be light. This simultaneously reduces wind flap and allows the jacket to stow away in a pocket. If you ride in town, our reflective BioViz® accents to catch the eye of passing drivers in low light conditions.

settings.title: Warmers
settings.text: Rides often start early and end some 20 degrees later. Arm warmers and leg warmers slip over limbs, allowing you to adjust your thermostat as the temperatures change. They are easy to pull off and tuck away into the jersey with little fuss.   Like bibs and jerseys, arm and leg warmers come in a variety of sizes. Find the right fit for your guns, as you don’t want the warmers to slip off. To help prevent them from falling down, layer arm and leg warmers under the jersey and bibs.

settings.title: Baselayers
settings.text: A baselayer will help keep you in the comfort sweet spot as temperatures fluctuate, but especially in cooler weather. They fit close to the body, under your bib straps, and pull sweat quickly off your skin. In warmer temps when you’re sweating more a baselayer will improve your cooling, to a point. We don’t recommend them above 90.  In cooler weather, the baselayer keeps you dryer and warmer. Choose a polyester Transfer base for all condition use, or cozy Merino wool for cooler rides.

settings.heading: FRESH AIR IN THE LUNGS,
settings.body: dust on the legs, sweeping landscapes in view — hitting the trail reaps huge physical and mental rewards. But if you’re putting rubber to the dirt for the first time, it can be a little intimidating. The right gear can make the transition to mountain biking more enjoyable.

settings.heading: We’ve outlined the basics to get you out and on the trail for miles of joy.

settings.title: Jersey
settings.text: Hot days on the trail are paid out in liters of sweat. You need a jersey that breathes well and wicks sweat quickly. Mountain bike jerseys fit looser for better airflow and are offered in sleeveless, T-shirt, zip front and tank styles. But don't assume their casual styling means they're any less technical.

settings.title: Shorts
settings.text: For mountain bikers, shorts provide as much protection from the unpredictability of the trail as they do the saddle. Padded Lycra bike shorts can pass in a pinch, but over time they will take a beating on the trail. Investing in a pair of dedicated mountain bike shorts will prove a better option.

settings.title: Shoes
settings.text: More durable than gym shoes, a dedicated mountain bike shoe provides a stable platform to transfer energy from your legs, through the bike, to the ground. Mountain bike shoes fall into two categories: flat pedal and clipless. Both should feel stiff, yet comfortable, and lock your heel into the cup. The choice depends on the type of riding you’ll do (and your comfort with unclipping from the bike).  Stepping off a flat pedal has zero learning curve, making it safer to tackle rocky terrain. Clipless pedals (contrary to the name) “clip” onto your shoes through a cleat bolted between the lugs. The cleats snap into the pedal, locking your foot into the bike. Twisting your foot unlocks it from the pedal. It takes some practice, but clipping into the pedals allows you to pull up and push down with each pedal stroke, providing maximum energy transfer between you and the trail. These are a great choice for more cross-country-oriented rides that don’t require constantly stepping in and out of the pedal.

settings.title: Gloves
settings.text: Gloves are one part grip, one part protection. Sweat or rain can make your grip slick. Gloves will keep you connected to the handlebars, prevent blisters, and, if you go down, you will appreciate the coverage. Even for sunny summer rides, we like full-finger gloves. A good pair should be lightweight and nimble, allowing you to work the levers without overheating.

settings.title: Liners
settings.text: You still need a chamois to protect your backside. The good news is that many MTB shorts include a padded liner short, but you can also choose to buy the outer short and liner separately if you want higher performance comfort.

settings.title: Socks
settings.text: Socks wick moisture away from the feet, offer a bit of cushioning, and can protect the lower legs from flogging by brush. Cycling socks are some of the very best socks you can buy. They stay up, are durable, and they’re fashionable enough to cross over into everyday wear. Taller socks can provide a little more protection, support, and warmth.

settings.title: Jacket
settings.text: Backcountry weather can be fickle. Summer afternoons can quickly shift from sunny to stormy in the flick of a gear. Like hikers, mountain bikers should prepare for the worst. Every rider should stow a simple jacket in the pack to unfurl with the change of weather. A waterproof-breathable jacket can protect you from a rainstorm, but it can often be too warm (and bulky) for riding. Unless you regularly ride in the rain, most riders will be better served with a water-resistant jacket. This will have a DWR coating to shed light rain, while the lightweight material helps cut through the wind and disappears in the pack. On cold morning rides, these jackets provide fantastic warmth when you point the rubber down the hill.

settings.title: Protection
settings.text: Terrain changes quickly when mountain biking, especially on trails you’re unfamiliar with. As you start to point the rubber down more technical terrain, consider knee and elbow pads. Protecting your knee and elbow joints ensures you’ll be ready to ride another day. A good pad will have some pre-curve to fit around the joint while allowing it to articulate.

settings.title: here we go.
settings.text: Go connection.

settings.body: To know where you are going, you first have to know where you came from. These are the moments that set our history in motion, and still push us forward today.

settings.title: 90 pounds. 38 miles.
settings.text:
Before there was a PEARL iZUMi, there was a man and a bike. He rode that bike 38 miles a day, every day. Not for exercise or for the fun of it, but to deliver 90 pounds of clothing to his customers in a neighboring village.
The year: 1950. The man’s name: Kinji Shimizu. And in fourteen short years, he’d go from lugging clothing on a bike to redefining what every cyclist wore on them.

settings.title: 1 in 15.
settings.text:
In 1964, one of Kinji’s sons, Hiro, raced for the Japanese national team at the Asian Cycling Championships. The team ordered its usual fourteen cotton kits. And a special fifteenth.
After the races, the team director filled a helmet with scraps of paper with each racer’s name. As fate would have it, Hiro’s name was pulled. He won the special jersey. It was made in Italy and 100% nylon. Unlike anything he’d ever seen before.

settings.title: Relentless force.
settings.text:
Later that year, Kinji created his first kit based on that made in Italy design. He used only the best materials he could find.
Kinji continued pushing his concepts. He was endless in his endeavors, constantly researching new fabrics and studying the body in motion.
Over the next five decades, this obsessive approach led to innovation after innovation. Building the very foundation for everything we do today.

settings.text_1: We innovate so you ride happier, more comfortably, drier, faster, warmer, and safer. Innovation not for innovation’s sake, but for the goal of making each product better than the last.
